numeric_premises.content: The probability of having severe weather during a specific time period varies greatly; having it from May 15th to June 14th is 0.254098, from June 15th to July 1st is 0.131148, from July 2nd to July 15th is 0.106557, from July 16th to August 10th is 0.213115, from August 11th to August 20th is 0.07377, and from August 20th to September 15th is 0.221312.

Scenario F has a 2% probability.

wep_based_premises.content: If the date is between May 15 and June 14, there is probably not a high chance of severe weather; from June 15 to July 1, it is improbable; from July 2 to July 15, there is little chance; from July 16 to August 10, it is unlikely; from August 11 to August 20, it is highly unlikely; and from August 20 to September 15, it is once again unlikely.

On May 15th to June 14th, the scenarios A, and I are predicted to be improbable, while scenarios B and K are considered unlikely. Scenarios E, G, H, and I have little chance of occurring, and there is almost no chance of scenario F and J. Scenarios C and D only have slight chances of occurring.

From June 15th to July 1st, the scenarios A, H, and I are highly unlikely, while scenario B is unlikely, whereas C, D, and G are improbable. Scenarios E and J have a little chance, and scenario K has a slight chance of happening. Finally, for scenario F there is almost no chance of occurring.

During July 2nd to 15th, scenarios A, H, and I are highly unlikely, while scenarios B, G, and K have a slight chance of occurring. Scenarios C, D, and E have a little chance, and scenario F has almost no chance. Scenario J is improbable, and scenario K has a slight chance of happening.

From July 16th to August 10th, scenarios A, D, G, H, and I are highly unlikely, while scenarios B and C have a slight chance of occurring. Scenario E is unlikely, and scenario F is improbable. Scenario J has a slight chance, and scenario K has a little chance of happening.
During August 11th to 20th, scenarios A, D, E, F, H, and I are highly unlikely, while scenarios B and J have a slight chance of occurring. Scenarios C, G, and K are improbable.
From August 20th to September 15th, scenarios A, B, D, and H are highly unlikely or improbable, while scenarios C, E, F, G, I, and J have a little to almost none chance. Scenario K is unlikely.

If the scenario is described as A, then the likelihood of various movement features is as follows: there is probably not a strong front, there is better than even odds of marked upper movement, it is unlikely that there are other rapid movements, and it is impossible for there to be no major movement.

If the scenario is classified as B, then the probability of different movement features is as follows: there is a very good chance of no major movement, there is only a slight chance of other rapid movements, it is improbable that there will be marked upper movement, and it is highly unlikely that there will be a strong front.

If the scenario is described as D, then the probability of different movement features is as follows: there is a slight chance of no major movement, and it is unlikely that there will be a strong front, marked upper movement, or other rapid movements.

If the scenario is described as E, then the likelihood of different movement features is as follows: there is almost no chance of a strong front or marked upper movement, it is probably not the case that there will be other rapid movements, and there is a probability of no major movement.

If the scenario is classified as F, then the probability of different movement features is as follows: there is a very good chance of no major movement, and it is highly unlikely that there will be a strong front, marked upper movement, or other rapid movements.

If the scenario is categorized as G, then the probability of different movement features is as follows: there is a slight chance of a strong front or other rapid movements, and it is probably not the case that there will be marked upper movement. There is an about even chance of no major movement.

If the scenario is described as H, then the likelihood of different movement features is as follows: it is impossible for there to be a strong front, there is little chance of other rapid movements, and it is unlikely that there will be no major movement. However, it is likely that there will be marked upper movement.

If the scenario is described as I, then the likelihood of different movement features is as follows: it is unlikely that there will be a strong front or other rapid movements, and there is little chance of marked upper movement. There is an about even chance of no major movement.

If the scenario is described as J, then the likelihood of different movement features is as follows: it is highly unlikely that there will be a strong front or other rapid movements, and it is impossible for there to be marked upper movement. There is a highly likely chance of no major movement.

Given that the scenario is categorized as K, then the probability of different movement features is as follows: there are about even chances of a strong front, and it is probably not the case that there will be marked upper movement. There is little chance of other rapid movements, and it is highly unlikely that there will be no major movement.

If Scenario A is in play, it is highly unlikely that the relative humidity ratio will change from Moist to Dry, but there is a better than even chance that it will change from Dry to Moist, while other changes are probably not going to happen.

In scenario B, the likelihood of a change from moist to dry conditions (MoistMDryL) is quite low, while the chances of a shift from dry to moist conditions (DryMMoistL) and other transitions (Other) are approximately equal.

In Scenario C, it is probably not the case that the relative humidity ratio represents a change from moist conditions to dry conditions (MoistMDryL), there is little chance that it represents a change from dry conditions to moist conditions (DryMMoistL), and there are about even chances that the relative humidity ratio represents other conditions (Other).

In Scenario D, it is unlikely that the relative humidity ratio represents a change from moist conditions to dry conditions (MoistMDryL), there are about even chances that it represents a change from dry conditions to moist conditions (DryMMoistL), and it is probably not the case that the relative humidity ratio represents other conditions (Other).

If scenario E occurs, it is probable that the relative humidity ratio will transition from moist to dry conditions, whereas it is highly unlikely that the relative humidity ratio will transition from dry to moist conditions. Additionally, it is improbable that the relative humidity ratio will change in any other way.

In scenario F, it is impossible for the relative humidity ratio to indicate a change from moist conditions to dry conditions (MoistMDryL) or from dry conditions to moist conditions (DryMMoistL). However, it is certain for the relative humidity ratio to indicate 'Other' in scenario F.

In Scenario G, the relative humidity ratio transitioning from MoistMDryL is better than even, while the relative humidity ratio changing from DryMMoistL is impossible, and a different relative humidity ratio scenario is probably not likely.

If the scenario is H, it is impossible for the relative humidity ratio to change from moist conditions to dry conditions, it is likely for the relative humidity ratio to change from dry conditions to moist conditions, and it is probably not the case that the the relative humidity ratio is in any other state.

In scenario I, it is improbable that the relative humidity ratio will display a transition from moist conditions to dry conditions (MoistMDryL), whereas it is probable that it will show a transition from dry conditions to moist conditions (DryMMoistL). However, it is considered unlikely that the relative humidity ratio will exhibit any other changes apart from these two (Other).

In scenario J, it is probably not the case that the relative humidity ratio will transition from moist to dry conditions (MoistMDryL), there are about even chances that the relative humidity ratio will transition from dry to moist conditions (DryMMoistL), and it is improbable that the relative humidity ratio will be anything else (Other).

If the scenario is K, it is improbable for the relative humidity ratio to indicate a change from moist conditions to dry conditions, there are about even chances for it to indicate a change from dry conditions to moist conditions, and it is probably not the case that it indicates any other scenario.
